newsitem.title: ROMANIA: ROMANIA EYES LOCOMOTIVE DEAL WITH SIEMENS.
newsitem.headline: ROMANIA EYES LOCOMOTIVE DEAL WITH SIEMENS.

text.p: Romania's main privatisation agency said on Friday it was negotiating with Siemens a possible joint venture between the German company and local Electroputere locomotive maker.
"Siemens made us an offer, we accepted it and we are now conducting talks," Daniel Branzan, spokesman for the State Ownership Fund (FPS) told Reuters.
The FPS has a controlling state in most Romanian state companies.
Branzan said details of the negotiations were confidential. "However, I think (Siemens) will seek a control stake in Electroputere, but it all depends on the result of the talks."

Electroputere, based in Craiova 250 km (155 miles) southwest of Bucharest, was once Eastern Europe's biggest producer of electric locomotives. It is a holding of seven production units manufacturing also electric motors, generators, power transformers and transport equipment.
If the deal with Siemens comes through, the new joint venture will assemble diesel locomotives and will upgrade electric locomotives and passenger railway cars.

Siemens AG has so far invested in another four companies in Romania, including a digital telephone exchange producer, a medical instruments maker, an electric cables manufacturer and a railway signalling technology firm.
Germany is the third largest single investor in Romania, with capital inflows worth $222.9 million injected since 1989, when Romania ended communist rule.
